title: How to Clean Clarisonic

steps.headline: Remove the brush head.
steps.description: It’s usually easier to clean a Clarisonic handle if you separate it from the brush head. Grip the brush head tightly and push it inward. Next, turn it counterclockwise and gently pull the brush head away from the handle. Set it aside. To avoid spreading any dirt, germs, or bacteria, set the brush head down with the bristles facing upward when you remove it from the handle.

steps.headline: Run the handle under warm water.
steps.description: The Clarisonic handle is waterproof, so you can rinse it to start the cleaning process. Turn the warm water on at the sink, and rinse the handle under it to get it wet. Avoid getting too much water in the interior of the handle where the brush head snaps into place.

steps.headline: Squirt some soap onto the handle and massage in.
steps.description: When the handle is damp, squeeze some dishwashing liquid soap onto it. Use clean fingers to gently rub the soap in, creating suds all over the surface of handle to remove dirt and germs. You can also use your usual facial cleanser to clean the Clarisonic handle.

steps.headline: Rinse the handle under water.
steps.description: After you’ve rubbed the soap all over the handle to clean it, turn the water back on at the sink. Run the handle under warm water again to remove all of the soapy residue and rinse it clean.

steps.headline: Dry the handle with a towel.
steps.description: Once the handle is fully rinsed, shake it off a couple of times to get rid of any excess moisture. Next, use a clean towel to carefully dry the handle and set it aside until you’re ready to reattach the brush head. It’s a good idea to wash your Clarisonic handle at least once a week to remove any buildup or residue. Be sure to shake the excess moisture from the interior of the brush as well. You may even want to use a small towel or cotton pad to dry the area where the brush head snaps in to make sure that there isn’t any water inside.

methods.name: Cleansing the Brush Head with Soap and Water

steps.headline: Rinse the brush head under warm water.
steps.description: After you’ve removed the brush head from the Clarisonic handle, turn on the warm water at your sink. Run the bristles under it to thoroughly wet them. You can also clean the brush head immediately after you’ve used the Clarisonic so the bristles are already damp.

steps.headline: Squeeze some soap onto the bristles.
steps.description: Once the brush head is damp, apply a small amount of dishwashing liquid to the bristles. If you prefer, you can use a hand soap or facial cleanser to wash the brush. It’s not necessary to use an antibacterial soap because the brush heads are made of nonporous nylon that is designed not to harbor germs or bacteria.

steps.headline: Massage the soap into the bristles.
steps.description: After you’ve applied the soap to the brush head, rub the bristles back and forth against your fingers or hand to really work the soap in. You should massage the soap into the brush for 30 seconds to 1 minute to ensure that it is fully clean. If the brush head seems particularly dirty, you may want to use a clean toothbrush to scrub the soap into the bristles and the surface of the brush head.

steps.headline: Run the brush head under water.
steps.description: When you’re finished working the soap into the bristles, turn the sink back on. Rinse the brush head under warm water to remove all of the dirt, oil, and soapy residue.

steps.headline: Set the brush head out to air dry.
steps.description: When the brush head is clean, allow it to sit out to air dry. You can replace it on the handle and let it dry like that, or leave the brush on a towel by itself to finish drying. You can place the brush cap back over the brush head even while it’s drying. The cap has holes in it to ventilate the brush head so air can still reach it to help it dry. You should remove your brush head and give it a thorough cleaning at least once a week. However, be sure to rinse the brush head well after each use. Even with proper cleaning, you should replace your Clarisonic brush heads every three months.

methods.name: Using Baking Soda and Hydrogen Peroxide on the Brush Head

steps.headline: Mix the baking soda and hydrogen peroxide.
steps.description: Add 2 parts baking soda to 1 part hydrogen peroxide in a small dish. Stir the two together well until a paste with a yogurt-like consistency forms. If the mixture is too dry, mix in more hydrogen peroxide. If the mixture is too liquidy, stir in more baking soda. EXPERT TIP																															Joanna Kula																Licensed Esthetician								Joanna Kula is the Lead Esthetician at Rescue Spa in Philadelphia. With over 8 years of experience in skin care, she specializes in transformative facial treatments. Joanna Kula			Licensed Esthetician				Use a solution of hydrogen peroxide once a week. You can soak the brush head in hydrogen peroxide for up to an hour once a week to clean any bacteria or residue. Allow the head to air dry and store it away from moisture. You should also replace the brush head every three months.

steps.headline: Add some lemon juice into the mixture.
steps.description: After the baking soda and hydrogen peroxide mixture has reached the right consistency, cut two to three slices off of a lemon. Squeeze the juice from the slices into the mixture, and stir well to combine. It is normally for the mixture to fizz when you add the lemon juice.

steps.headline: Spin the brush head in the mixture for a minute.
steps.description: With the brush head attached to the Clarisonic handle, turn on the device. Allow the head to spin in the baking soda, hydrogen peroxide, and lemon juice mixture for 30 seconds to 1 minute so the bristles are thoroughly coated. If you prefer not to run the Clarisonic as you clean the bristles, you can remove the brush head from the handle and dip it in the mixture. Swish it around the mixture for 30 seconds, and then rub it against your palm to work the cleanser into the bristles.

steps.headline: Run the brush head against a towel.
steps.description: After you’ve allowed the brush head to spin in the cleanser for about a minute, take it out of the mixture. Run it against a clean towel for another minute or two to allow all of the dirt and residue to come loose. The dirt from the brush head may stain your towel so be sure to use an old one that you don’t mind getting dirty.

steps.headline: Rinse the brush head with water.
steps.description: With the brush head still running on the Clarisonic, turn the warm water on at your sink. Run the brush under it under all of the dirt and cleanser residue is removed.

steps.headline: Repeat the process until the brush head is clean and air dry.
steps.description: If your Clarisonic brush head is particularly dirty, you may need to repeat the entire cleansing process more than once. When you’re satisfied that it’s completely clean, allow it sit out on your counter with the brush cap in place to dry completely. You can use the baking soda and hydrogen peroxide mixture to clean your brush head weekly, or you can save it for times when the bristles are looking particularly dirty.

methods.name: Mixing Vinegar and Soap to Clean the Brush

steps.headline: Combine the vinegar, dish soap, essential oils, and water.
steps.description: Add 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of liquid dish soap, 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of vinegar, 3 drops of anti-fungal essential oils of your choice, and enough warm water to make the mixture deep enough for soak the brush head to a small bowl or jar. Mix the ingredients well to ensure that they’re fully blended. You can use white or apple cider vinegar for the cleanser. Some anti-fungal essential oils to consider for the cleanser include lemon, lavender, thyme, oregano, tea tree, geranium, chamomile, and cedarwood. Lemon essential oil has the added benefit of helping to brighten the brush head’s bristles.

steps.headline: Place the brush in the mixture and allow it to soak.
steps.description: After you’ve mixed up the cleanser, set the Clarisonic in the mixture with the bristles facing down. Let the brush soak in the mixture for about 30 minutes so the cleanser has time to work. You can remove the brush head from the Clarisonic handle or place the entire device in the mixture to soak. Just make sure that the bristles are facing down.

steps.headline: Scrub the entire brush.
steps.description: When the bristles have soaked in the cleanser for a while, lift it out of the mixture. Use a cloth or toothbrush to scrub the brush head and the handle to help remove any lingering dirt and residue.

steps.headline: Rinse the brush and towel dry it.
steps.description: Once you’ve scrubbed the Clarisonic brush head and handle well, turn the warm water on at the sink. Run the device under the water to rinse away the dirt and cleanser residue. Use a clean towel to pat the Clarisonic dry so it’s ready for your next use. Even if you pat the Clarisonic dry, you should leave it out to air dry for several hours before you use it again.

tyn: Baking Soda and Hydrogen Peroxide Brush Head Cleanser
3 drops anti-fungal essential oils of your choice

Next, turn it counterclockwise and gently pull the brush head away from the handle. Set it aside. To avoid spreading any dirt, germs, or bacteria, set the brush head down with the bristles facing upward when you remove it from the handle. Run the handle under warm water. The Clarisonic handle is waterproof, so you can rinse it to start the cleaning process. Turn the warm water on at the sink, and rinse the handle under it to get it wet. Avoid getting too much water in the interior of the handle where the brush head snaps into place. Squirt some soap onto the handle and massage in. When the handle is damp, squeeze some dishwashing liquid soap onto it. Use clean fingers to gently rub the soap in, creating suds all over the surface of handle to remove dirt and germs. You can also use your usual facial cleanser to clean the Clarisonic handle. Rinse the handle under water. After you’ve rubbed the soap all over the handle to clean it, turn the water back on at the sink. Run the handle under warm water again to remove all of the soapy residue and rinse it clean. Dry the handle with a towel. Once the handle is fully rinsed, shake it off a couple of times to get rid of any excess moisture. Next, use a clean towel to carefully dry the handle and set it aside until you’re ready to reattach the brush head. It’s a good idea to wash your Clarisonic handle at least once a week to remove any buildup or residue. Be sure to shake the excess moisture from the interior of the brush as well. You may even want to use a small towel or cotton pad to dry the area where the brush head snaps in to make sure that there isn’t any water inside. sentences: Washing the Handle Remove the brush head.
It’s usually easier to clean a Clarisonic handle if you separate it from the brush head.
Grip the brush head tightly and push it inward.
Next, turn it counterclockwise and gently pull the brush head away from the handle.
Set it aside.
To avoid spreading any dirt, germs, or bacteria, set the brush head down with the bristles facing upward when you remove it from the handle.
Run the handle under warm water.
The Clarisonic handle is waterproof, so you can rinse it to start the cleaning process.
Turn the warm water on at the sink, and rinse the handle under it to get it wet.
Avoid getting too much water in the interior of the handle where the brush head snaps into place.
Squirt some soap onto the handle and massage in.
When the handle is damp, squeeze some dishwashing liquid soap onto it.
Use clean fingers to gently rub the soap in, creating suds all over the surface of handle to remove dirt and germs.
You can also use your usual facial cleanser to clean the Clarisonic handle.
Rinse the handle under water.
After you’ve rubbed the soap all over the handle to clean it, turn the water back on at the sink.
Run the handle under warm water again to remove all of the soapy residue and rinse it clean.
Dry the handle with a towel.
Once the handle is fully rinsed, shake it off a couple of times to get rid of any excess moisture.
Next, use a clean towel to carefully dry the handle and set it aside until you’re ready to reattach the brush head.
It’s a good idea to wash your Clarisonic handle at least once a week to remove any buildup or residue.
Be sure to shake the excess moisture from the interior of the brush as well.
You may even want to use a small towel or cotton pad to dry the area where the brush head snaps in to make sure that there isn’t any water inside.
Cleansing the Brush Head with Soap and Water Rinse the brush head under warm water.
After you’ve removed the brush head from the Clarisonic handle, turn on the warm water at your sink.
Run the bristles under it to thoroughly wet them.
You can also clean the brush head immediately after you’ve used the Clarisonic so the bristles are already damp.
Squeeze some soap onto the bristles.
Once the brush head is damp, apply a small amount of dishwashing liquid to the bristles.
If you prefer, you can use a hand soap or facial cleanser to wash the brush.
It’s not necessary to use an antibacterial soap because the brush heads are made of nonporous nylon that is designed not to harbor germs or bacteria.
Massage the soap into the bristles.
After you’ve applied the soap to the brush head, rub the bristles back and forth against your fingers or hand to really work the soap in.
You should massage the soap into the brush for 30 seconds to 1 minute to ensure that it is fully clean.
If the brush head seems particularly dirty, you may want to use a clean toothbrush to scrub the soap into the bristles and the surface of the brush head.
Run the brush head under water.
When you’re finished working the soap into the bristles, turn the sink back on.
Rinse the brush head under warm water to remove all of the dirt, oil, and soapy residue.
Set the brush head out to air dry.
When the brush head is clean, allow it to sit out to air dry.
You can replace it on the handle and let it dry like that, or leave the brush on a towel by itself to finish drying.
You can place the brush cap back over the brush head even while it’s drying.
The cap has holes in it to ventilate the brush head so air can still reach it to help it dry.
You should remove your brush head and give it a thorough cleaning at least once a week.
However, be sure to rinse the brush head well after each use.
Even with proper cleaning, you should replace your Clarisonic brush heads every three months.
Using Baking Soda and Hydrogen Peroxide on the Brush Head Mix the baking soda and hydrogen peroxide.
Add 2 parts baking soda to 1 part hydrogen peroxide in a small dish.
Stir the two together well until a paste with a yogurt-like consistency forms.
If the mixture is too dry, mix in more hydrogen peroxide.
If the mixture is too liquidy, stir in more baking soda.

Joanna Kula			Licensed Esthetician				Use a solution of hydrogen peroxide once a week.
You can soak the brush head in hydrogen peroxide for up to an hour once a week to clean any bacteria or residue.
Allow the head to air dry and store it away from moisture.
You should also replace the brush head every three months.
Add some lemon juice into the mixture.
After the baking soda and hydrogen peroxide mixture has reached the right consistency, cut two to three slices off of a lemon.
Squeeze the juice from the slices into the mixture, and stir well to combine.
It is normally for the mixture to fizz when you add the lemon juice.
Spin the brush head in the mixture for a minute.
With the brush head attached to the Clarisonic handle, turn on the device.
Allow the head to spin in the baking soda, hydrogen peroxide, and lemon juice mixture for 30 seconds to 1 minute so the bristles are thoroughly coated.
If you prefer not to run the Clarisonic as you clean the bristles, you can remove the brush head from the handle and dip it in the mixture.
Swish it around the mixture for 30 seconds, and then rub it against your palm to work the cleanser into the bristles.
Run the brush head against a towel.
After you’ve allowed the brush head to spin in the cleanser for about a minute, take it out of the mixture.
Run it against a clean towel for another minute or two to allow all of the dirt and residue to come loose.
The dirt from the brush head may stain your towel so be sure to use an old one that you don’t mind getting dirty.
Rinse the brush head with water.
With the brush head still running on the Clarisonic, turn the warm water on at your sink.
Run the brush under it under all of the dirt and cleanser residue is removed.
Repeat the process until the brush head is clean and air dry.
If your Clarisonic brush head is particularly dirty, you may need to repeat the entire cleansing process more than once.
When you’re satisfied that it’s completely clean, allow it sit out on your counter with the brush cap in place to dry completely.
You can use the baking soda and hydrogen peroxide mixture to clean your brush head weekly, or you can save it for times when the bristles are looking particularly dirty.
Mixing Vinegar and Soap to Clean the Brush Combine the vinegar, dish soap, essential oils, and water.

Add 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of liquid dish soap, 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of vinegar, 3 drops of anti-fungal essential oils of your choice, and enough warm water to make the mixture deep enough for soak the brush head to a small bowl or jar.
Mix the ingredients well to ensure that they’re fully blended.
You can use white or apple cider vinegar for the cleanser.
Some anti-fungal essential oils to consider for the cleanser include lemon, lavender, thyme, oregano, tea tree, geranium, chamomile, and cedarwood.
Lemon essential oil has the added benefit of helping to brighten the brush head’s bristles.
Place the brush in the mixture and allow it to soak.
After you’ve mixed up the cleanser, set the Clarisonic in the mixture with the bristles facing down.
Let the brush soak in the mixture for about 30 minutes so the cleanser has time to work.
You can remove the brush head from the Clarisonic handle or place the entire device in the mixture to soak.
Just make sure that the bristles are facing down.
Scrub the entire brush.
When the bristles have soaked in the cleanser for a while, lift it out of the mixture.
Use a cloth or toothbrush to scrub the brush head and the handle to help remove any lingering dirt and residue.
Rinse the brush and towel dry it.
Once you’ve scrubbed the Clarisonic brush head and handle well, turn the warm water on at the sink.
Run the device under the water to rinse away the dirt and cleanser residue.
Use a clean towel to pat the Clarisonic dry so it’s ready for your next use.
Even if you pat the Clarisonic dry, you should leave it out to air dry for several hours before you use it again.
